title: BadGraph: A Backdoor Attack Against Latent Diffusion Model for Text-Guided Graph Generation
summary: This paper introduces BadGraph, a novel backdoor attack targeting latent diffusion models for text-guided graph generation, a critical technology in areas like drug discovery. The attack leverages textual triggers to poison training data, covertly implanting backdoors that compel the model to generate attacker-specified subgraphs when triggers are present during inference, all while preserving normal performance on benign inputs. BadGraph demonstrates high efficacy (over 80% attack success rate with 24% poisoning) and stealth, exposing significant security vulnerabilities in these generative AI models.

title: Predicting Protein-Nucleic Acid Flexibility Using Persistent Sheaf Laplacians
summary: This research introduces the Persistent Sheaf Laplacian (PSL) framework for accurately predicting the flexibility of protein-nucleic acid complexes, characterized by atomic B-factors. By integrating multiscale analysis, algebraic topology, and sheaf theory, PSL overcomes the limitations of traditional models, demonstrating significantly improved performance across diverse datasets. The method's enhanced accuracy offers promising avenues for understanding complex biomolecular interactions essential for function, reactivity, and allosteric pathways.

title: Acoustic Emission Cascade Predicting Progression to Failure of Rock and Bone
summary: This research investigates the progression of Acoustic Emission (AE) event rates in quasi-brittle materials, specifically rock and bone, under fixed loading conditions leading to failure. The study identifies a predictable "quasi-linear cascade of the inverse AE energy rate" preceding failure, consistent with a rate-dependent material failure law. This AE cascade provides a critical warning of impending failure for both materials, offering a significant window for intervention in medical applications.

title: ACS-SegNet: An Attention-Based CNN-SegFormer Segmentation Network for Tissue Segmentation in Histopathology
summary: This paper introduces ACS-SegNet, a novel attention-based dual-encoder network that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers (ViTs) for enhanced semantic tissue segmentation in histopathological images. The model achieved superior performance, with μIoU/μDice scores of 76.79%/86.87% on the GCPS dataset and 64.93%/76.60% on the PUMA dataset, outperforming state-of-the-art benchmarks. This advancement aims to significantly improve automated computer-aided diagnosis in pathology.

title: Empathic Prompting: Non-Verbal Context Integration for Multimodal LLM Conversations
summary: Empathic Prompting is a novel multimodal framework that enriches Large Language Model (LLM) conversations by unobtrusively integrating implicit non-verbal emotional cues from users. It utilizes a facial expression recognition service to embed affective information as contextual signals during prompting, aiming to improve conversational smoothness and alignment. A preliminary evaluation demonstrated consistent integration of this non-verbal input into coherent LLM outputs, enhancing conversational fluidity.

title: Automated Extraction of Fluoropyrimidine Treatment and Treatment-Related Toxicities from Clinical Notes Using Natural Language Processing
summary: This paper developed and evaluated various Natural Language Processing (NLP) methods to automate the extraction of fluoropyrimidine treatment and associated toxicities from clinical notes. The study found that Large Language Model (LLM)-based approaches, particularly error-analysis prompting, achieved superior performance (F1=1.000) compared to traditional machine learning, deep learning, and rule-based methods. This highlights the potential of LLMs to enhance oncology research and pharmacovigilance by efficiently extracting crucial clinical information.

title: Optimizing Clinical Fall Risk Prediction: A Data-Driven Integration of EHR Variables with the Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool
summary: This study developed a data-driven constrained score optimization (CSO) model to enhance the Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool (JHFRAT) for inpatient fall risk prediction. The CSO model, integrating EHR variables while maintaining interpretability, significantly improved predictive performance (AUC-ROC 0.91) compared to the original JHFRAT (AUC-ROC 0.86). This approach offers a robust, evidence-based method for health systems to optimize fall prevention protocols and improve patient safety.
keywords: Johns Hopkins Fall Risk Assessment Tool

title: GRACE: GRaph-based Addiction Care prEdiction
summary: This paper introduces GRACE, a novel graph neural network (GNN) framework designed to predict the appropriate locus of care for addiction patients, a critical clinical decision often hindered by resource scarcity and data class imbalance. GRACE formalizes this as a structured learning problem, employing extensive feature engineering and a new unbiased meta-graph approach to address class imbalance. Experimental results on real-world data show a significant improvement of 11-35% in the F1 score for the minority class over existing baselines.

title: xTime: Extreme Event Prediction with Hierarchical Knowledge Distillation and Expert Fusion
summary: xTime is a novel framework designed for accurate prediction of rare, high-impact extreme events in time series data, such as acute medical episodes or significant physiological spikes. It addresses challenges like data imbalance and the neglect of information from intermediate events by integrating hierarchical knowledge distillation and a mixture of experts mechanism. The framework demonstrated substantial improvements in forecasting accuracy for extreme events, ranging from 3% to 78% across various datasets.

title: Better Tokens for Better 3D: Advancing Vision-Language Modeling in 3D Medical Imaging
summary: BTB3D introduces a novel causal convolutional encoder-decoder that unifies 2D and 3D training for vision-language modeling in 3D medical imaging, generating compact, frequency-aware volumetric tokens. This approach addresses limitations of existing models in handling high-resolution CT volumes, significantly improving performance in both automated medical report generation and text-to-CT synthesis. It underscores that precise three-dimensional tokenization is critical for scalable vision-language modeling in this domain.

title: Deep Learning in Dental Image Analysis: A Systematic Review of Datasets, Methodologies, and Emerging Challenges
summary: This systematic review comprehensively analyzes deep learning (DL) applications in dental image analysis (DIA) by reviewing 260 studies, focusing on datasets, methodologies, and emerging challenges. It addresses issues like low contrast and metallic artifacts in dental imaging, which hinder accurate manual diagnosis. The paper aims to provide a structured reference for researchers by detailing existing datasets, categorizing DL models for various DIA tasks, and discussing evaluation metrics, current limitations, and future research directions.

title: Equitable Survival Prediction: A Fairness-Aware Survival Modeling (FASM) Approach
summary: This paper introduces Fairness-Aware Survival Modeling (FASM) to address algorithmic bias in machine learning models used in healthcare, particularly focusing on disparities in cross-group risk rankings within survival analysis. Applied to breast cancer prognosis using SEER data, FASM substantially improves fairness and mitigates misranking across patient groups, while preserving discrimination performance comparable to fairness-unaware models. The approach demonstrates stable fairness improvements over a 10-year horizon, especially in the mid-term follow-up.

title: PSO-XAI: A PSO-Enhanced Explainable AI Framework for Reliable Breast Cancer Detection
summary: This paper introduces PSO-XAI, an integrated framework that leverages customized Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for feature selection to enhance breast cancer detection. Evaluated across 29 diverse machine learning models, the framework achieved a superior 99.1% performance across all metrics while reducing dimensionality. It also provides transparent, model-agnostic explanations, demonstrating the potential of explainable AI combined with swarm intelligence for robust and trustworthy clinical diagnostics.

title: The Dog the Cat Chased Stumped the Model: Measuring When Language Models Abandon Structure for Shortcuts
summary: This paper introduces CenterBench, a novel dataset designed to evaluate when language models (LMs) abandon structural syntactic analysis in favor of semantic pattern matching. It demonstrates that LMs systematically prioritize semantic plausibility over precise syntactic understanding as sentence complexity increases, revealing a fundamental difference in how models and humans process complex language structures.

title: Fitness inference tested by in silico population genetics
summary: This paper investigates the feasibility of inferring fitness parameters and genotype fitness order from time-stratified, whole-genome sequencing data in populations evolving under natural selection, mutation, and recombination. Through *in silico* simulations, the authors delineated specific parameter ranges where accurate fitness inference is possible and others where it is not. The work establishes a framework for determining the reliability of fitness inference from population-wide genomic data, particularly relevant for understanding the evolution of human pathogens.

title: On Multiple Robustness of Proximal Dynamic Treatment Regimes
summary: This paper addresses the critical challenge of estimating optimal dynamic treatment regimes (DTRs) using observational data, particularly when the crucial unconfoundedness assumption fails due to unmeasured confounders. It proposes a novel framework based on proximal causal inference to identify and learn these adaptive treatment strategies, introducing robust methodologies validated for efficiency and reliability.

title: MolBridge: Atom-Level Joint Graph Refinement for Robust Drug-Drug Interaction Event Prediction
summary: MolBridge is a novel atom-level joint graph refinement framework designed to predict drug-drug interaction (DDI) events with high accuracy and robustness. It addresses the limitations of existing methods by explicitly modeling atom-level cross-molecular interactions within a joint graph and utilizing a structure consistency module to overcome over-smoothing challenges. This approach leads to superior performance across diverse molecular complexities, including long-tail and inductive scenarios, offering enhanced mechanistic interpretability.

title: Dynamic Weight Adjustment for Knowledge Distillation: Leveraging Vision Transformer for High-Accuracy Lung Cancer Detection and Real-Time Deployment
summary: This paper introduces the FuzzyDistillViT-MobileNet model, a novel approach for high-accuracy lung cancer (LC) classification. It employs dynamic fuzzy logic-driven knowledge distillation, where a Vision Transformer (ViT-B32) instructor transfers knowledge to a MobileNet student, allowing for adaptive weight adjustment based on regional uncertainty in medical images. This method achieves high diagnostic accuracy on both histopathological and CT-scan datasets while being optimized for real-time deployment.

title: Identification and Debiased Learning of Causal Effects with General Instrumental Variables
summary: This paper introduces a general nonparametric framework for identifying and estimating causal effects using multi-categorical or continuous instrumental variables (IVs). It proposes an additive IV framework to identify mean potential outcomes and the average treatment effect (ATE) via weighting functions, employing debiased machine learning (DML) for consistent and asymptotically normal estimation.

title: Contrast-enhanced X-ray imaging of articular cartilage: reliability of a cationic contrast agent in combination with high-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography system
summary: This study developed and validated a novel contrast-enhanced X-ray imaging method using a cationic contrast agent (CA4+) with high-resolution peripheral quantitative computed tomography (HR-pQCT) to quantify proteoglycan content in articular cartilage. It successfully demonstrated significant correlations between the enhanced radiopacity, directly linked to proteoglycan content, and the viscoelastic mechanical properties of healthy bovine articular cartilage. This approach shows promise for early and precise detection of cartilage degeneration.

title: Bias by Design? How Data Practices Shape Fairness in AI Healthcare Systems
summary: This paper highlights how biased data collection practices are a major barrier to integrating AI into real-world clinical practice, despite AI's promise for healthcare transformation. Drawing insights from Spain's AI4HealthyAging project, the authors identify historical, representation, and measurement biases affecting critical variables, offering practical recommendations to improve fairness and robustness in clinical problem design and data collection for future AI healthcare systems.

title: Enhancing Security in Deep Reinforcement Learning: A Comprehensive Survey on Adversarial Attacks and Defenses
summary: This comprehensive survey analyzes the critical issue of security and robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) systems, particularly in the face of adversarial attacks. It introduces a novel classification framework for these attacks, detailing methods that perturb state, action, reward, and model spaces. The paper also systematically reviews various defense strategies, discussing their strengths and weaknesses, and outlines future research directions for enhancing DRL security in sensitive applications like smart healthcare.

title: DB-FGA-Net: Dual Backbone Frequency Gated Attention Network for Multi-Class Classification with Grad-CAM Interpretability
summary: This paper introduces DB-FGA-Net, a novel dual-backbone deep learning model that integrates VGG16 and Xception with a Frequency-Gated Attention Block for highly accurate and interpretable multi-class brain tumor classification. The model achieves state-of-the-art performance without data augmentation, demonstrating robustness and strong generalization, and integrates Grad-CAM for clinical interpretability and a GUI for real-time deployment.

title: Classical Feature Embeddings Help in BERT-Based Human Mobility Prediction
summary: This paper introduces STaBERT (Semantic-Temporal aware BERT), a novel BERT-based model designed to significantly enhance human mobility forecasting by integrating both derived temporal descriptors and Points of Interest (POI) embeddings. It addresses the shortcomings of existing models that either neglect POI semantics or treat time as mere auxiliary input, thereby failing to capture rich contextual information. Experimental results demonstrate STaBERT's superior performance, boosting GEO-BLEU scores dramatically for both single-city (0.34 to 0.75) and multi-city (0.34 to 0.56) predictions.

title: GMFVAD: Using Grained Multi-modal Feature to Improve Video Anomaly Detection
summary: GMFVAD introduces a novel approach to video anomaly detection by leveraging 'grained multi-modal features' to address the issue of redundant information in visual features. It enhances specific, highlighted visual portions of video snippets with text features derived from captions, leading to more refined anomaly detection. The method achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets, with its improvement directly attributed to the reduction of redundant information.

title: Tri-Modal Severity Fused Diagnosis across Depression and Post-traumatic Stress Disorders
summary: This paper introduces a unified tri-modal framework that synchronizes and fuses interview text, audio, and facial signals to diagnose and assess graded severity for co-occurring depression (PHQ-8, 5 classes) and PTSD (3 classes). The severity-aware approach outperforms unimodal baselines, enhances diagnostic utility and robustness, and provides explainable feature attributions, offering clinician decision support.

title: Towards Objective Obstetric Ultrasound Assessment: Contrastive Representation Learning for Fetal Movement Detection
summary: This paper introduces Contrastive Ultrasound Video Representation Learning (CURL), a novel self-supervised framework designed for objective and accurate fetal movement (FM) detection from ultrasound videos. Addressing the subjectivity of traditional methods, CURL utilizes a dual-contrastive loss and a task-specific sampling strategy to learn robust motion representations. Evaluated on an in-house dataset, it achieved a sensitivity of 78.01% and an AUROC of 81.60%, demonstrating potential for improved prenatal monitoring.

title: Assessing the Feasibility of Early Cancer Detection Using Routine Laboratory Data: An Evaluation of Machine Learning Approaches on an Imbalanced Dataset
summary: This study evaluated the feasibility of early cancer detection in dogs using machine learning on routine laboratory data, addressing challenges like non-specific biomarkers and severe class imbalance. While a statistically detectable cancer signal was found (AUROC=0.815), the optimal model demonstrated poor clinical classification performance (F1=0.25, PPV=0.15), indicating that routine lab data alone are insufficient for reliable early cancer diagnosis or rule-out.

title: A Structured Review and Quantitative Profiling of Public Brain MRI Datasets for Foundation Model Development
summary: This study systematically reviews and quantitatively profiles 54 publicly available brain MRI datasets (over 538,031 entries) to assess their suitability for foundation model development. It uncovers significant imbalances between healthy and clinical cohorts, substantial heterogeneity in image characteristics, and persistent inter-dataset variability even after standardized preprocessing. The research confirms measurable residual covariate shift in feature space, highlighting that current harmonization methods are insufficient to eliminate inter-dataset bias.

title: SPAN: Continuous Modeling of Suspicion Progression for Temporal Intention Localization
summary: SPAN (Suspicion Progression Analysis Network) introduces a paradigm shift in Temporal Intention Localization (TIL) by moving from discrete classification to continuous regression for modeling suspicious intentions in video surveillance. Leveraging insights from Temporal Point Process theory, SPAN defines a continuous suspicion score, integrates multimodal information to modulate suspicion coefficients, and links actions to predefined concepts for enhanced explainability. This approach significantly improves detection accuracy, particularly for subtle behavioral changes, enabling earlier intervention and greater utility in security applications.
domains: Geriatrics (e.g., fall prediction, monitoring cognitive decline, wandering)
Psychiatry (e.g., early detection of agitation, self-harm ideation, behavioral changes in dementia)
Neurology (e.g., seizure onset detection, monitoring progression of movement disorders)
Rehabilitation (e.g., adherence to exercise protocols, detecting fatigue or improper form)
Patient Safety (e.g., identifying precursors to adverse events in hospitals or assisted living)
Remote Patient Monitoring (e.g., continuous behavioral tracking for chronic conditions)

title: Understanding Mechanistic Role of Structural and Functional Connectivity in Tau Propagation Through Multi-Layer Modeling
summary: This paper investigates the intricate interplay of structural (SC) and functional connectivity (FC) in driving tau propagation in Alzheimer's disease (AD) using a multi-layer graph diffusion model and extensive longitudinal neuroimaging data. It reveals that SC and FC exhibit regionally and temporally asymmetric contributions to tau spread, with these patterns aligning with AD-associated gene expression and being modulated by risk factors like APOE genotype and amyloid deposition.

title: Why Prototypes Collapse: Diagnosing and Preventing Partial Collapse in Prototypical Self-Supervised Learning
summary: This paper diagnoses prototype collapse in self-supervised learning (SSL) as a direct consequence of joint encoder-prototype optimization, which encourages redundant representations. It introduces a fully decoupled training strategy where prototypes are modeled as a Gaussian mixture updated via an online EM-style procedure, independent of the encoder's loss. This method effectively eliminates prototype collapse without regularization, yielding diverse prototypes and stronger downstream performance, which is critical for robust medical AI.

title: Extending machine learning model for implicit solvation to free energy calculations
summary: This paper introduces Lambda Solvation Neural Network (LSNN), a novel graph neural network (GNN)-based implicit solvent model designed to overcome limitations of existing machine learning (ML) methods in calculating absolute free energies. By training LSNN on both force-matching and the derivatives of alchemical variables, the authors achieved solvation free energy predictions with accuracy comparable to explicit-solvent simulations, offering significant computational speedup and enabling meaningful comparisons across chemical species, particularly for drug discovery applications.

title: ShapeX: Shapelet-Driven Post Hoc Explanations for Time Series Classification Models
summary: This paper introduces ShapeX, a novel framework designed to provide explainable AI for time series classification models by focusing on shapelets. ShapeX segments time series into meaningful shapelet-driven segments and utilizes Shapley values to assess their saliency, thereby addressing the crucial need for transparency in high-stakes applications like healthcare. The framework demonstrates superior precision and causal fidelity in identifying relevant subsequences compared to existing explanation methods, grounding explanations in causal relationships rather than mere correlations.
domains: Critical Care Medicine (vital signs monitoring, sepsis prediction)
Endocrinology (continuous glucose monitoring for diabetes management)
Wearable Health Technology (activity recognition, anomaly detection)

title: Ask What Your Country Can Do For You: Towards a Public Red Teaming Model
summary:
AI systems have the potential to produce both benefits and harms, but without
rigorous and ongoing adversarial evaluation, AI actors will struggle to assess
the breadth and magnitude of the AI risk surface. Researchers from the field of
systems design have developed several effective sociotechnical ...

title: Endogenous Aggregation of Multiple Data Envelopment Analysis Scores for Large Data Sets
summary: This paper introduces two novel regularized Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) models, SBM and GP-SBM, for dynamic, multi-dimensional efficiency evaluation in large healthcare datasets. These models integrate both desirable and undesirable outputs to generate dimension-specific and aggregate efficiency scores, demonstrating superior performance over conventional methods in capturing input/output correlations. The approach is designed for large-scale problems and applied to assess hospital effectiveness across technical, clinical, and patient experience dimensions.

title: BrainPuzzle: Hybrid Physics and Data-Driven Reconstruction for Transcranial Ultrasound Tomography
summary: BrainPuzzle addresses the significant challenges of transcranial ultrasound tomography (TUT) by proposing a novel hybrid physics- and data-driven framework. It overcomes the limitations of both traditional physics-based full-waveform inversion and purely data-driven methods, achieving superior accuracy and completeness in speed-of-sound (SoS) map reconstruction for brain imaging, even under low signal-to-noise and sparse-aperture conditions.

title: AI Pose Analysis and Kinematic Profiling of Range-of-Motion Variations in Resistance Training
summary: This study introduces an AI-based pose estimation pipeline for precise kinematic quantification in resistance training, comparing lengthened partial (pROM) and full (fROM) ranges of motion. It found that pROM repetitions had smaller ROM and shorter durations, especially during the eccentric phase, and identified participant-level variations as the primary driver of differences. The research proposes a novel, consistent metric, "%ROM", highlighting the utility of AI for advancing resistance training research and prescription.

title: Improving Predictive Confidence in Medical Imaging via Online Label Smoothing
summary: This paper introduces Online Label Smoothing (OLS), a dynamic approach to enhance predictive confidence and accuracy in deep learning models for medical image classification. By adjusting soft labels based on the model's real-time prediction patterns, OLS consistently improves classification accuracy and calibration compared to traditional methods, leading to more trustworthy AI systems in healthcare.

title: Beyond MedQA: Towards Real-world Clinical Decision Making in the Era of LLMs
summary: This paper proposes a new unifying paradigm for evaluating Large Language Models (LLMs) in clinical decision-making, moving beyond simplified Question-Answering datasets like MedQA that underrepresent real-world complexity. The paradigm characterizes tasks along 'Clinical Backgrounds' and 'Clinical Questions' dimensions, aiming to standardize comparisons, clarify assumptions, and guide the development of clinically meaningful LLMs.

title: RELATE: A Schema-Agnostic Perceiver Encoder for Multimodal Relational Graphs
summary: RELATE introduces a schema-agnostic Perceiver encoder designed for multimodal relational graph data, addressing the scalability issues of existing GNNs that use schema-specific feature encoders. It leverages shared modality-specific encoders and a Perceiver-style cross-attention module to generate fixed-size node representations. Evaluated on RelBench, RELATE achieves performance comparable to schema-specific encoders (within 3%) while drastically reducing parameter counts by up to 5x, facilitating multi-dataset pretraining and foundation models for relational graph analysis.

title: Drug-disease networks and drug repurposing
summary: This research introduces a novel, comprehensively curated drug-disease network, leveraging diverse data sources and natural language processing. The study applies network-based link prediction methods, particularly graph embedding and network model fitting, to accurately identify potential drug-disease associations for repurposing, achieving significantly high prediction performance (AUC > 0.95, Average Precision ~1000x chance).

title: FINDER: Feature Inference on Noisy Datasets using Eigenspace Residuals
summary: FINDER is a novel, rigorous framework designed for robust classification in 'noisy' or data-deficient datasets, prevalent in many scientific domains. It leverages fundamental stochastic analysis, mapping empirical data to 'stochastic features' in Hilbert spaces, and then employs the Kosambi-Karhunen-Loève expansion (KLE) and eigen-decomposition to identify distinct class regions. This approach has achieved state-of-the-art breakthroughs, notably in Alzheimer's Disease stage classification.

title: Enhancing Diagnostic Accuracy for Urinary Tract Disease through Explainable SHAP-Guided Feature Selection and Classification
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach utilizing SHAP-based feature selection to enhance diagnostic accuracy and transparency for urinary tract diseases, specifically bladder cancer. By developing six binary classification scenarios with XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost, the methodology demonstrates that SHAP-guided feature selection effectively maintains or improves performance metrics like balanced accuracy, precision, and specificity, leading to more transparent and efficient clinical decision support systems.

title: FairGRPO: Fair Reinforcement Learning for Equitable Clinical Reasoning
summary: This paper introduces FairGRPO, a hierarchical reinforcement learning approach designed to mitigate performance disparities of medical AI across diverse demographic groups, which often suffer harm from biased systems. FairGRPO employs adaptive importance weighting and unsupervised clustering for latent group discovery, demonstrating significant reductions in predictive parity (27.2%) and improvements in F1 score (12.49%) across various clinical diagnostic tasks, culminating in the release of FairMedGemma-4B, a fairness-aware clinical VLLM.

title: Enabling Granular Subgroup Level Model Evaluations by Generating Synthetic Medical Time Series
summary:
We present a novel framework for leveraging synthetic ICU time-series data
not only to train but also to rigorously and trustworthily evaluate predictive
models, both at the population level and within fine-grained demographic
subgroups. Building on prior diffusion and VAE-based generators (TimeDiff...

title: Compressing Biology: Evaluating the Stable Diffusion VAE for Phenotypic Drug Discovery
summary: This paper systematically evaluates the Stable Diffusion's Variational Autoencoder (SD-VAE) for reconstructing high-dimensional microscopy images from Cell Painting screens, which are central to phenotypic drug discovery. It quantitatively demonstrates that SD-VAE effectively preserves phenotypic signals with minimal loss, validating the use of general-purpose generative models in this domain. Furthermore, the study shows that off-the-shelf feature extractors like InceptionV3 perform comparably or superiorly to bespoke models in biological retrieval tasks, offering practical guidelines to simplify future drug discovery pipelines.
